cluster_relations.rel_desc: The varying story specifics contrast with the constant fear of the unknown.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: story specifics of the Hook Man legend
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Urban Legend Emotional Themes and Responses

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: specifics of the story may vary
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: NarrativePattern: surface variation vs. stable emotional theme

remarks: Used contrast relation to encode that one varies while the other is stable.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The variable story specifics contrast with the constant perceived threat of danger.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: story specifics of the Hook Man legend
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Urban Legend Emotional Themes and Responses

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: across versions of the Hook Man legend
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: specifics of the story may vary
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: NarrativePattern: changing plot elements vs. fixed danger theme

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The truth behind the stories is conceptually contrasted with fictional elements in the tales.
remarks: Relation added to reflect contrast; less explicit than fact-truth link.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two narrative elements or concepts are set in opposition or conceptual contrast to highlight their differences.
args.justification: All three relations explicitly encode a contrast between two narrative concepts (varying story specifics vs. stable emotional themes; truth vs. fiction). They share the same symmetric predicate meaning of conceptual opposition, so they should use a single normalized canonical predicate 'contrasts_with'.

Each relation captures a conceptual opposition between two narrative constructs (e.g., variable specifics vs. constant fear/threat, truth vs. fiction). Grouping them under a class 'conceptual_contrast_relation' reflects this shared function of highlighting opposing concepts within narratives.

Contrast is a form of comparative association between two concepts, linking them by highlighting their differences. This is neither compositional nor causal but a relational comparison, which fits best under a broad 'ASSOCIATION' group.
